Description: Rim and body sherd of South Ionian pottery cup with everted rim; interior: on rim, three black black bands; glazed black on body; top of rim glazed; exterior: myrtle leaf pattern with row of added white dots; handle zone reserved with band at top; glazed below.
Type series: Schlotzhauer little master Ionian Cup type
Curator's comments: Venit (1982 68, A57), when discussing a Corinthian aryballos (actually British Museum 1924,1201.1217) gave the registration number for this rim sherd. The error was then taken up by Möller (2000 221, no. 5). Schlotzhauer identifies the sherd a belonging to his group of South Ionian little master cups and South Ionian cups with everted rim Type 9B. These cups coincide with Hayes’ Ionian Cup Type XI (Boardman and Hayes 1966, 111-116). These cups have been found in other sanctuary settings including at the Sanctuary of Demeter and Kore at Tocra. The Type 9 shape evolved from the earlier Type 5 cup shape. Hayes suggested a Rhodian origin for these types of cups but this is uncertain (Boardman and Hayes 1966, 114). Schlotzhauer points out that the same myrtle pattern is found on Fikellura style pottery from Miletus and thus suggest a South Ionian or more specifically Milesian origin for the cups (Schlotzhauer 2012, 108-9).
The decoration on the inside of the rim is rare, parallelled on 1965,0930.662, which is from a different cup.
Bibliographic references: Schlotzhauer 2012 / Untersuchungen zur archaischen griechischen Keramik aus Naukratis (p. 52, no. 298)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GE.813) (Phase 3)
